items.question: NAPE mistakenly notifies the wrong tenderer (X) instead of the rightful lowest bidder (Y) due to a typing error. X accepts. Y claims the contract. The legal position is:
options: A) Contract with X is valid due to postal rule
B) No valid contract exists as consensus ad idem is absent between NAPE's intention and X's acceptance
C) Both X and Y have valid contracts
D) Contract vests in Y automatically

items.question: Baber contracts for 50 computers with delivery by March 1. After repeated delays and assurances until May, he refuses final delivery. If the contract specified time as essence:
options: A) Baber cannot refuse as he accepted delays
B) Baber's conduct waived the time clause, but he can refuse if reasonable notice given
C) Automatic termination occurred on March 1

items.question: Mr. Brown sells his car to Mr. Green who then discovers a better deal elsewhere. If Green refuses delivery claiming breach:
options: A) Green can claim the price difference
B) Green has no claim as no loss from breach if he got a better deal

items.question: Contractors demand extra payment for building due to unexpected labor costs and threaten to stop work. The owner agrees under protest. This agreement is:
options: B) Voidable due to economic duress

items.question: Mr. Zulfiqar is offered a professorship conditional on canceling his practicing license. He cancels it but is then refused employment. His remedy:
options: A) No remedy as conditional offer
B) Damages for detrimental reliance/promissory estoppel

items.question: Tanweer receives offer for washing machines from A (Rs.25,000) and B (Rs.23,000). He posts acceptance to B and tells A verbally he'll consider. B's letter is delayed. Meanwhile, A treats silence as acceptance and delivers. The legal position:
options: A) Contract with A due to conduct
B) Contract with B when posted regardless of delay

items.question: In a sale of seeds, extensive inspection reveals defects after delivery. If inspection was unreasonably prolonged:
options: B) Buyer deemed to have accepted by conduct

items.question: A agrees to sell property to B. Unknown to both, government had acquired it under eminent domain. The contract is:
options: B) Void for mutual mistake as to existence of subject matter

items.question: Arif buys a used car based on salesperson's statement "one-owner, excellent condition" which proves false. Salesperson genuinely believed it true based on documents. This constitutes:
During negotiations, seller knows buyer needs goods for specific lucrative contract but doesn't disclose imminent law change banning such use. After sale, law changes. Buyer's position:
options: A) No remedy due to caveat emptor
B) Rescission for fraudulent concealment of material fact

items.question: Gama, Maja, and Billoo are partners. Gama retires with proper internal agreement but no public notice. Billoo orders goods using old letterhead showing all three names. Supplier seeks payment from:
options: B) All three including retired Gama due to lack of public notice

items.question: After Asif & Babar partnership dissolution, Asif uses old letterhead to order goods, adding "dissolved" in small print. Supplier doesn't notice the addition. Liability lies with:
options: B) Both partners as dissolution notice insufficient

items.question: In painters' partnership, employee negligently splashes paint on expensive carpet while partner diverts customer payments for gambling. The firm's liability:
options: B) For both employee's tort and partner's fraud in course of business

items.question: Partnership deed allows expulsion by majority vote. Two partners expel third citing "incompetence" but real reason is to acquire his share cheaply. The expulsion is:
options: B) Void for bad faith/improper motive
C) Voidable at expelled partner's option

items.question: A partner commits to arbitration without consulting others, waiving firm's strong legal claim. The arbitration agreement:
options: A) Binds the firm as within apparent authority
B) Void as beyond implied authority without consent

items.question: Partnership property includes a lease. One partner secretly negotiates new lease in personal name when old expires. The new lease:
options: B) Held in constructive trust for firm

items.question: Retiring partner agrees to non-compete but continues advising old clients without charge. When firm sues, the legal position:
options: A) No breach as no payment
B) Breach regardless of gratuitous nature

items.question: Minor admitted to partnership benefits becomes major but doesn't give notice within 6 months. Subsequently, firm incurs huge debt. Minor's position:
options: A) Not liable as minor when admitted
B) Fully liable as failed to give notice
C) Liable only for benefits received

items.question: Partners agree to submit disputes to arbitration. One partner bribes arbitrator. Other partner discovers this after adverse award. Remedy available:
options: B) Court can set aside for arbitrator misconduct

items.question: Dormant partner's identity discovered by third party who then extends credit. When firm defaults, dormant partner claims no liability:
options: B) Liable once identity known and credit extended

items.question: Company's memorandum authorizes "trading in goods." Directors use profits to build dam claiming it's for "hydroelectric power for factory." This is:
options: A) Valid as incidental to main object
B) Ultra vires unless fairly incidental to trading

items.question: Promoter contracts for company before incorporation without disclosing non-existence. After incorporation, company uses benefits but denies liability. Legal position:
options: B) Company liable by conduct/implied adoption

items.question: Articles require special notice for removing director. Director removed without notice claims wrongful removal. Company argues business judgment. Court will:
options: B) Invalidate removal for procedural breach

items.question: Company issues shares to X. Y claims pre-emption rights under articles were violated. X is bona fide purchaser without notice. The share transfer:
options: B) Valid to X but company/directors liable to Y

items.question: Directors enter major contract without required board resolution. Third party unaware of internal requirement. Under indoor management rule:
options: B) Company bound, directors personally liable
C) Third party should have checked

items.question: Subsidiary company is used to circumvent parent's legal obligations. Creditors seek to pierce corporate veil. Court will examine:
options: B) Whether subsidiary is mere facade/agent

items.question: Company alters objects clause to enter new business. Minority shareholders claim oppression as this devalues their investment. The alteration:
options: B) Can be challenged if unfairly prejudicial

items.question: Director uses inside information to trade in company shares through spouse's account. When caught, claims no personal trading. Legal position:
options: B) Liable for insider trading despite indirect route

items.question: Company in financial distress. Directors prefer related party creditors before declaring insolvency. Other creditors challenge. The payments:
Two companies share directors who cause first to sell assets below value to second. Minority shareholders of first company:
options: A) No remedy against second company
B) Can pursue both companies and directors

items.question: Jamal steals bearer cheque, forges endorsement (unnecessary for bearer), and transfers to innocent Kamal who gives value. Bank dishonors citing theft. Kamal's position:
options: A) No rights due to theft
B) Valid holder as bearer instrument transferable by delivery

items.question: Bill of exchange accepted by drawee. Before maturity, acceptor adds "subject to goods being satisfactory." Holder claims this invalidates acceptance. Legal position:
options: C) Holder can treat as dishonored
D) Both B and C correct

items.question: A draws bill on B payable to C. C endorses to D, who endorses to E. E alters amount and negotiates to F (holder in due course). F's rights:
options: B) Can recover original amount from parties before alteration
C) Can recover altered amount from E

items.question: Accommodation bill drawn by A on B for B's benefit. B negotiates to C mentioning accommodation nature. C negotiates to D without disclosure. D's rights against A:
options: B) Full rights as holder in due course
D) Rights subject to proof of consideration

items.question: Cheque dated Sunday presented on Monday. Bank refuses citing "impossible date." Legal position:
options: B) Valid as presumed dated previous/next day

items.question: Series of post-dated cheques given. Drawer dies after first encashed but before others presented. Bank's duty:
options: B) Cannot honor after notice of death

items.question: Foreign bill dishonored. Holder immediately returns home without protesting. Seeks to sue drawer. Drawer's defense:
options: B) Failure to protest foreign bill discharges drawer

items.question: Cheque crossing states "Account Payee Only" but transferred through endorsements. Final holder presents. Bank's position:
options: B) Cannot pay except to original payee's account

items.question: Minor draws promissory note for education loan. On majority, claims no liability. Legal position:
options: B) Voidable but necessaries exception may apply

items.question: Bill payable at bank. Presented day before maturity. Bank refuses saying "present on due date." Holder treats as dishonored. Legal effect:
Seller delivers goods knowing buyer's intended illegal use but says nothing. Buyer later claims refund when caught. Legal position:
options: B) No remedy as seller not party to illegality

items.question: Sale "subject to satisfactory survey." Buyer delays survey for months then rejects citing defects. Seller claims waiver. Court will examine:
Goods sold "as per sample" with additional description "finest quality." Goods match sample but not "finest." Buyer's rights:
options: A) No remedy if matches sample
B) Can reject for breach of description

items.question: CIF contract where goods destroyed after shipment but before payment. Seller tenders documents. Buyer refuses citing destruction. Legal position:
options: B) Must pay against conforming documents

items.question: Buyer inspects goods, notes minor defects, takes delivery saying "subject to adjustment." Later rejects for same defects. Legal position:
options: B) Acceptance with known defects waives rejection

items.question: Unpaid seller exercises lien. Buyer becomes insolvent. Liquidator demands delivery claiming lien lost. Seller's position:
Seller retains title until payment but allows buyer possession for retail sale. Buyer sells to innocent customer then defaults. Original seller claims goods from customer:
options: B) Customer gets good title as buyer in possession

items.question: Software sold with shrink-wrap license visible only after purchase. Terms exclude all warranties. Defect causes data loss. Warranty exclusion:
options: B) Ineffective as not part of sale contract

items.question: Auctioneer announces "without reserve" but withdraws lot when bidding low. Highest bidder sues. Legal position:
options: B) Breach of contract with highest bidder

items.question: Goods delivered in installments. First two accepted, third defective. Buyer rejects entire contract. Seller claims only third installment rejectable:
options: B) Depends if defect goes to whole contract

items.question: Arbitration clause states "all disputes." Party claims tort of negligence outside contract. Arbitrability depends on:
options: B) Whether tort claim relates to contractual relationship

items.question: Arbitrator decides case on "equity and good conscience" without parties' agreement for such approach. Award is:
options: B) Liable to be set aside for legal error

items.question: During arbitration, criminal allegations surface. Arbitrator continues and awards damages. Party claims criminal aspects need court. Legal position:
options: A) Arbitrator cannot touch criminal aspects
B) Can decide civil aspects despite criminal overlap

items.question: Three arbitrators. Two sign award, third refuses claiming improper consultation. Award's validity:
options: B) Valid if majority properly consulted

items.question: Arbitration award contains speaking order revealing arbitrator met one party privately. Other party discovers through award itself. Remedy:
options: A) No remedy as award final
B) Set aside for apparent bias/misconduct

items.question: Party challenges arbitrator appointment after participating fully and losing. Claims arbitrator was contractually disqualified. Court's approach:
options: B) Waiver by participation without objection

items.question: Arbitration agreement requires reasoned award. Arbitrator gives one-line decision. Losing party challenges. Court will:
options: B) Remit for reasons or set aside

items.question: International arbitration award requires enforcement locally. Defendant claims against public policy citing tax evasion. Court examines:
options: B) Only if fundamental public policy violation

items.question: Arbitrator awards specific performance of property sale. Defendant claims arbitrators cannot grant equitable relief. Legal position:
options: A) Only courts grant equitable relief
B) Arbitrators have full civil court powers unless excluded

items.question: Death of sole arbitrator after hearing but before award. Legal effect:
options: B) Fresh arbitration unless parties agree otherwise

items.question: Agent authorized to sell property but not below Rs.1 million. Sells for Rs.900,000 to buyer who knows limitation but agent says "principal desperately needs money." Principal's position:
options: B) Can repudiate as buyer knew limitation

items.question: Del credere agent guarantees buyer's payment. Buyer defaults citing defective goods. Agent's liability:
options: C) Only if agent at fault

items.question: Company director purports to act as agent in personal capacity. Third party deals thinking director acts officially. Company benefits. Legal position:
Agent secretly acts for both buyer and seller in property deal without disclosure. Discovers fraud and reports to both. Commission claim:
options: B) Forfeits all rights due to breach of fiduciary duty

items.question: Power of attorney authorizes "all acts except sale." Agent mortgages property saying it's not a sale. Mortgagee seeks enforcement. Principal's defense:
options: B) Mortgage beyond authority as substantively similar

items.question: Agent instructed to buy goods "at best price." Buys from relative at higher price without disclosure. Principal discovers after using goods. Remedy:
options: B) Secret profit recoverable despite use

items.question: Insurance agent fills form incorrectly despite correct information from client. Claim rejected for misstatement. Client's recourse:
options: B) Agent/insurer liable as agent's knowledge imputed

items.question: Estate agent introduces buyer but deal completes months later through different agent. First agent claims commission. Entitlement depends on:
options: B) Whether introduction was effective cause

items.question: Agent with authority to collect cash deposits cheques in personal account then absconds. Principal sues bank. Bank's liability:
options: B) Liable if collected irregularly inconsistent with authority

items.question: Minor acts as agent, contracts on principal's behalf. Third party later discovers minority and claims no liability. Legal position:
options: B) Principal bound, minor agent not personally liable

items.question: Life insurance policy taken with deliberate misstatement of age. Insured dies after 10 years. Insurer discovers misstatement. Legal position:
options: B) Proportionate adjustment based on correct premium

items.question: Divorced wife beneficiary in husband's policy. Husband remarries but doesn't change beneficiary, then dies. Both wives claim. Legal position:
options: B) Depends on policy terms and jurisdiction

items.question: Marine insurance on goods. Ship deviates from route for crew emergency then sinks. Insurer denies claim citing deviation. Legal position:
options: B) Justified deviation for emergency doesn't void

items.question: Fire insurance excludes "riot damage." During political protest, miscreants set fire. Insurer denies citing exclusion. Insured's argument:
options: B) Proximate cause is fire, not riot

items.question: Competition Commission finds pharmaceutical companies exchanging pricing information through trade association. Companies claim efficiency. Legal assessment:
options: B) Object or effect of restricting competition

items.question: Dominant e-commerce platform offers deep discounts forcing competitors out then raises prices. Competition law violation:
Merger creates 60% market share. Parties claim efficiency gains. Commission's test:
options: B) Substantial lessening of competition despite efficiencies

items.question: Exclusive dealing arrangement between manufacturer and distributors. New entrant complains. Assessment considers:
Cartel participant provides evidence under leniency. Later withdraws cooperation citing threats. Commission's response:
options: B) Can revoke leniency for non-cooperation

items.question: Hub-and-spoke conspiracy where manufacturer coordinates pricing through vertical agreements with retailers. Legal analysis:
options: B) Vertical agreements facilitating horizontal conspiracy

items.question: Smart contract automatically executes payment on blockchain. Coding error causes overpayment. Recovery depends on:
options: B) Legal remedies exist despite automation

items.question: Digital signature certificate expired day before crucial contract signed. Discovered after performance. Contract validity:
options: B) Technical defect, substantial compliance suffices

items.question: AI system authorized to make routine purchases exceeds parameters buying expensive items. Company denies liability. Legal position:
options: B) Ostensible authority if held out as agent

items.question: Cryptocurrency payment made for goods. Value crashes before delivery. Seller demands extra payment or cancellation. Buyer's position:
options: B) Risk of value change on seller after payment

items.question: Terms of service updated on website with clause "continued use implies acceptance." Major arbitration clause added. User unaware but continues. Binding effect:
options: B) Depends on reasonable notice of material changes

items.question: Intermediary platform's algorithm promotes defamatory content about business. Business sues platform. Platform claims mere conduit. Liability:
options: B) Loses immunity if algorithm actively promotes

items.question: Cross-border data transfer violates local privacy laws. Contract has foreign jurisdiction clause. Local authorities act. Legal position:
options: B) Mandatory local law overrides contract

items.question: Electronic auction glitch allows bid after closing time which appears highest. Auctioneer refuses honoring citing rules. Bidder's claim:
options: B) Promissory estoppel if relied on display

items.question: Ransomware attack during electronic fund transfer. Hacker diverts funds. Bank claims customer's weak security. Liability:
options: B) Depends on security standards and notification

items.question: NFT sold representing digital art. Buyer discovers seller had no rights to underlying art. NFT ownership versus art rights:
options: B) Separate rights requiring specific transfer

items.question: Partnership, company, and agency issues converge: Partners form company, one acts beyond authority committing company, claims partnership liable. Analysis:
options: B) Piercing veil if company is partnership's alter ego

items.question: Sale, negotiable instrument, and fraud: Buyer gives post-dated cheque for goods. Stops payment claiming fraud. Seller negotiated cheque to holder in due course. Multiple claims:
options: B) Holder's rights subject to fraud defense availability

items.question: Insurance, arbitration, and limitation: Policy requires arbitration within one year of loss. Claim filed after 11 months, arbitration begins after year. Insurer claims time-bar:
options: B) Award must be within limitation

items.question: Company, contract, and competition: Directors of competing companies agree market division through their companies. Companies claim directors exceeded authority. Competition violation:
options: B) Companies liable for directors' anti-competitive acts

items.question: Electronic transaction, agency, partnership: Partner uses firm's digital credentials for personal transaction. Third party unaware. Transaction's binding effect:
Sale, arbitration, frustration: COVID lockdown prevents delivery. Arbitration clause says arbitrator decides "according to fairness." Arbitrator excuses performance. Challenge based on:
Guarantee, misrepresentation, discharge: Surety induced by creditor's misrepresentation about debtor's finances. Debtor defaults. Surety discovers misrepresentation after paying. Recourse:
options: B) Restitution from creditor for fraudulent inducement

items.question: Company debentures, trust deed, competing claims: Floating charge crystallizes same day company creates specific charge. Priority depends on:
options: B) Notice and conduct at crystallization

items.question: International sale, currency, force majeure: Contract in dollars, payment in local currency at exchange rate. Government bans dollar transactions. Seller claims force majeure. Analysis:
options: B) Must pay in alternative legal manner

items.question: Holding out, ratification, limitation: Person allows being represented as partner. Tort claim arises. Actual partners later ratify his acts for business benefit. Limitation runs from:
